entry.title: Fort Pearson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that during the 1879 Anglo-Zulu War a British soldier committed suicide by throwing himself off the 300-foot-high (90 m) cliffs at Fort Pearson (depicted)?

entry.title: Chase Brown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Canadian running back Chase Brown ranked second in American college football with 1,643 rushing yards in 2022?

entry.title: Church of St Giles, Stoke Poges (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Church of St Giles, Stoke Poges, which is claimed to have inspired the "Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard", is featured in a James Bond film?

entry.title: Edward Thonen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Edward Thonen, one of the miners killed in the Eureka Rebellion, had gained notoriety in England as a jewellery thief prior to his emigration to Australia?

entry.title: Overwatch (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that although Blizzard's franchise Overwatch is centered around video games, its lore is mainly told through animated shorts, comics, and novels?

entry.title: Azio Corghi (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Azio Corghi composed his second and third operas with author José Saramago – the second for La Scala in Milan, and the third for a 1993 premiere at the Theater Münster?

entry.title: The Pagan School (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Charles Baudelaire wrote "The Pagan School" in opposition to the veneration of Pan in 19th-century France?

entry.title: Poetic Essay of the Great Bliss of the Sexual Union of Heaven and Earth and Yin and Yang (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the "Poetic Essay of the Great Bliss of the Sexual Union of Heaven and Earth and Yin and Yang" argues that heterosexual sex is the "ultimate human pleasure", but affirms homosexuality as well?
